 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with signs of urosepsis with
   atrial tachycardia/AFib presenting for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube
   appears to be properly functioning and is no longer an active issue.
   His urine has grown out <[**2112**] GNR
s, so unlikely a true infection and
   no longer and active issue. He also has sputum with Pseudomonas,
   currently being treated, which likely is a true infection. In his
   workup at this hospital it was learned that he has a cirrhotic liver,
   with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated IgG, and had
   significant ascites that has been 9L tapped, and now s/p a second tap
   to assess for resolution. Current active issues are the
   etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and
   managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most
   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing
   loculated effusions.
   1. Liver failure: Patient was found to have cirrhosis and ascites on
   imaging.  He had a paracentesis a couple days ago and 9L was removed
   and had a second [**Doctor First Name **] yesterday to assess for resolution, which showed
   less PMN's. Cx's from last [**Doctor First Name **] and Gstain from yesterday's [**Doctor First Name **] have
   been negative. Also with positive [**Doctor First Name **], positive anti-smooth muscle Ab
   and elevated IgG, consistent with autoimmune hepatitis etiology. Pt
   received some albumin with [**Doctor First Name **] yesterday.
   - F/u albumin this morning to calculate SAAG, but according to albumin
   from 4 days ago, would have SAAG <1.1 (0.5), differential including:
   peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, pancreatitis, vasculitides,
   hypoalbumin states, bowel obstruction, post-operative lymph leak
   note, pt received albumin yesterday after [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] this mornings add-on
   albumin will reflect this and his calculated SAAG using this will not
   be correct.
   - Added on amylase and lipase to this am's labs
   - F/u Cx's from most recent [**First Name3 (LF) **] yesterday
   - F/u with Hepatology today
   - Invite Hepatology to family meeting tomorrow at Wednesday 2pm
   2. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus. Have consulted Cards who rec an
   Amiodarone load then maintenance, which the pt was on in the past and
   stopped due to liver/lung issues. We have elected not to restart the
   Amiodarone due to this history of issues, but have started him on Dig
   instead.
   - Dig level is not elevated, will continue dosage as is.
   - Will get Dig level tomorrow morning
   - Received some IV Labatelol yesterday
   3. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt was on Cefepime/[**Name (NI) **], but yesterday d/c'd [**Name (NI) **]
   - Today is day 6 of Cefepime of 15 day course
   4. Fluid status--CXR with mild-mod pulm edema yesterday
   - Currently on Lasix gtt, will continue, now at 15mg / hr with goals
   150 cc/hr and 1-2L off per day.
   - Still about 5L positive today through LOS, but this may not reflect
   the 9L taken off during first [**Name (NI) **].
   5. Positive UA--Yesterday. On admission, concern for urosepsis but UCx
   only grow out <[**2112**] GNR's. Now with UA conerning for infxn yesterday,
   and have sent off UCx this am. Having low grade 100 temps for a couple
   days. WBC's at 9
   - F/u UCx.
   - Continues on Cefepime.
   - Hold off on starting new ABx for now but will consider broadening if
   urine Cx grows out
   6. Loculated pleural effusions, R > L.
   - Unsure what to do with this result in face of overall goals of care.
   Will be addressed at family meeting today whether to be aggressive with
   this or not.
   - Will need f/u of final CT read
   - Consult IP about draining them today, and if we proceed, will need to
   have Argatroban stopped for procedure.
   7. UA with persistent eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial
   nephritis, in setting of persistently elevated Cr. DDx includes
   allergic rxn to drugs, infxns including pyelonephritis, and
   infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma, leukemia.
   - Renal consult this am about eosinophilia.
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess for pyelonephritis, although was not
   seen on last CT abdomen/pelvis done recently
   8. Drifting down Hct: Has been slowly going down through admission and
   likely a consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to
   argatroban. No obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes.
   Had iron studies this admission showing low level iron and labs
   consistent with anemia of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most
   recent UA, but urine is clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be
   hemodynamically relevant, but will need to watch and consider if
   continued drop in Hct.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Watch vitals signs
   - Will get pm Hct
   - Has triple lumen subclavian and L PIV
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   9. Persistent respiratory failure: Reportedly on vent for the last 6
   mos.  Failure to wean could be both pneumonia as well as component of
   weakness, echo findings of RV dysfunction suggesting possible PE
   (unable to anticoagulate d/t persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or
   persistent pleural effusions due to persistent ascites.
   - Had SBT yesterday but got tachy and sweaty after several hours so put
   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   10. H/o HIT with need to be anticoagulated. LENI's are negative
   - Started on Argatroban gtt for PE prophylaxis per Heme recs with goal
   PTT 40-60
   - Currently within range at 0.2 mcg/kg/hr with PTT 50 so will continue
   as is
   11. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Will increase free water via G tube to 300 q4hrs, but is a delicate
   balance between lowering pt
s hypernatremia and trying to get fluids
   off him with Lasix gtt
   - Measure pm Na
   12. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   13. Acute on Chronic Renal failure: Likely a chronic renal
   insufficiency with Cr
s in the 2
s on admission. Lasix diuresis at OSH
   was also limited by renal failure. Of note, UA came back positive for
   urine eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial nephritis.
   - Renal consult in setting of positive urine eosinophils concerning for
   AIN.
   - Cr is chronically elevated, but will continue to trend.  Is 2.4 this
   morning, within recent baseline.
   - renally dose meds
   - Watch UOP through today
   11. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   12. S/P CABG: Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   13. Depression:
   - Continue Paxil
   14. "Funny Carotids" No signs of stroke, neuro exam WNL. Not an active
   issue.
   - carotid dopplers with <40% stenosis
   - not active issue
   15. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   16. G-tube malfunction: functioning per surgery, Radiology and nursing.
   Surgery has signed off. Not an active issue
   FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, systemic Argatroban
   Access: L subclavian triple lumen. R art line, L PIV. Will need to have
   PICC placed, likely today, and can d/c subclavian line after that.
   Code:  DNR, already tracheally intubated.
   Communication: Patient, daughter [**Name (NI) **]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home); cell:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement --> Have set up a family
   meeting for Wednesday at 2pm with daughter and will need to discuss
   goals of care.

   3. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt was on Cefepime/[**Name (NI) **], but yesterday d/c'd [**Name (NI) **]
   - Today is day 6 of Cefepime of 15 day course
   4. Fluid status--CXR with mild-mod pulm edema yesterday
   - Currently on Lasix gtt, will continue, now at 15mg / hr with goals
   150 cc/hr and 1-2L off per day.
   - Still about 5L positive today through LOS, but this may not reflect
   the 9L taken off during first [**Name (NI) **].
   5. Positive UA--Yesterday. On admission, concern for urosepsis but UCx
   only grow out <[**2112**] GNR's. Now with UA conerning for infxn yesterday,
   and have sent off UCx this am. Having low grade 100 temps for a couple
   days. WBC's at 9
   - F/u UCx.
   - Continues on Cefepime.
   - Hold off on starting new ABx for now but will consider broadening if
   urine Cx grows out
   6. Loculated pleural effusions, R > L.
   - Unsure what to do with this result in face of overall goals of care.
   Will be addressed at family meeting today whether to be aggressive with
   this or not.
   - Will need f/u of final CT read
   - Consult IP about draining them today, and if we proceed, will need to
   have Argatroban stopped for procedure.
   7. UA with persistent eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial
   nephritis, in setting of persistently elevated Cr. DDx includes
   allergic rxn to drugs, infxns including pyelonephritis, and
   infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma, leukemia.
   - Renal consult this am about eosinophilia.
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess for pyelonephritis, although was not
   seen on last CT abdomen/pelvis done recently
   8. Drifting down Hct: Has been slowly going down through admission and
   likely a consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to
   argatroban. No obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes.
   Had iron studies this admission showing low level iron and labs
   consistent with anemia of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most
   recent UA, but urine is clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be
   hemodynamically relevant, but will need to watch and consider if
   continued drop in Hct.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Watch vitals signs
   - Will get pm Hct
   - Has triple lumen subclavian and L PIV
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   9. Persistent respiratory failure: Reportedly on vent for the last 6
   mos.  Failure to wean could be both pneumonia as well as component of
   weakness, echo findings of RV dysfunction suggesting possible PE
   (unable to anticoagulate d/t persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or
   persistent pleural effusions due to persistent ascites.
   - Had SBT yesterday but got tachy and sweaty after several hours so put
   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   10. H/o HIT with need to be anticoagulated. LENI's are negative
   - Started on Argatroban gtt for PE prophylaxis per Heme recs with goal
   PTT 40-60
   - Currently within range at 0.2 mcg/kg/hr with PTT 50 so will continue
   as is
   11. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Will increase free water via G tube to 300 q4hrs, but is a delicate
   balance between lowering pt
s hypernatremia and trying to get fluids
   off him with Lasix gtt
   - Measure pm Na
   12. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   13. Acute on Chronic Renal failure: Likely a chronic renal
   insufficiency with Cr
s in the 2
s on admission. Lasix diuresis at OSH
   was also limited by renal failure. Of note, UA came back positive for
   urine eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial nephritis.
   - Renal consult in setting of positive urine eosinophils concerning for
   AIN.
   - Cr is chronically elevated, but will continue to trend.  Is 2.4 this
   morning, within recent baseline.
   - renally dose meds
   - Watch UOP through today
   11. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   12. S/P CABG: Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   13. Depression:
   - Continue Paxil
   14. "Funny Carotids" No signs of stroke, neuro exam WNL. Not an active
   issue.
   - carotid dopplers with <40% stenosis
   - not active issue
   15. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   16. G-tube malfunction: functioning per surgery, Radiology and nursing.
   Surgery has signed off. Not an active issue
   FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, systemic Argatroban
   Access: L subclavian triple lumen. R art line, L PIV. Will need to have
   PICC placed, likely today, and can d/c subclavian line after that.
   Code:  DNR, already tracheally intubated.
   Communication: Patient, daughter [**Name (NI) **]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home); cell:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement --> Have set up a family
   meeting for Wednesday at 2pm with daughter and will need to discuss
   goals of care.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with signs of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and g-tube evaluation. He has a history of cirrhosis, ascites, and autoimmune hepatitis. Current active issues include managing his cirrhosis, arrhythmia, pseudomonas pneumonia, and positive urine culture with eosinophils.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis is likely to progress, leading to further liver damage and potential liver failure.
2. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease is likely to worsen, and acute kidney injury may occur due to the presence of eosinophils in the urine.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may worsen due to the presence of pleural effusions, ascites, and potential pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture with eosinophils and pseudomonas pneumonia may lead to sepsis, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
5. Arrhythmia: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to potential cardiac complications.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's pseudomonas pneumonia may progress, leading to further respiratory failure.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypovolemic hypernatremia may worsen, leading to potential neurological complications.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to potential cardiovascular complications.
9. Acute interstitial nephritis: The patient's positive urine culture with eosinophils may lead to acute interstitial nephritis, which could worsen his kidney function.
10. Dehiscence: The patient's separation of the sternal wound may lead to dehiscence, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's liver function and kidney function closely.
2. Manage the patient's arrhythmia with anti-arrhythmic medications.
3. Continue antibiotics for pseudomonas pneumonia and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely, particularly sodium and potassium.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider vasopressors if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's kidney function closely and consider dialysis if necessary.
8. Consider a renal consult to further evaluate the patient's kidney function and potential acute interstitial nephritis.
9. Consider a cardiology consult to further evaluate the patient's arrhythmia and potential cardiac complications.
10. Consider a gastroenterology consult to further evaluate the patient's cirrhosis and potential liver failure.

   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with signs of urosepsis with
   atrial tachycardia/AFib presenting for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube
   appears to be properly functioning and is no longer an active issue.
   His urine has grown out <[**2112**] GNR
s, so unlikely a true infection and
   no longer and active issue. He also has sputum with Pseudomonas,
   currently being treated, which likely is a true infection. In his
   workup at this hospital it was learned that he has a cirrhotic liver,
   with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated IgG, and had
   significant ascites that has been 9L tapped, and now s/p a second tap
   to assess for resolution. Current active issues are the
   etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and
   managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most
   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils.
   1. Liver failure: Patient was found to have cirrhosis and ascites on
   imaging.  He had a paracentesis a couple days ago and 9L was removed
   and had a second para yesterday to assess for resolution, which showed
   less PMN's. Cx's from last para and Gstain from yesterday's para have
   been negative. Also with positive [**Doctor First Name **], positive anti-smooth muscle Ab
   and elevated IgG, consistent with autoimmune hepatitis etiology. Pt
   received some albumin with para yesterday.
   - F/u albumin this morning to calculate SAAG, but according to albumin
   from 4 days ago, would have SAAG <1.1 (0.5), differential including:
   peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, pancreatitis, vasculitides,
   hypoalbumin states, bowel obstruction, post-operative lymph leak
   - Added on amylase and lipase to this am's labs
   - F/u Cx's from most recent para yesterday
   - F/u with Hepatology today
   - Invite Hepatology to family meeting tomorrow at Wednesday 2pm
   2. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus. Have consulted Cards who rec an
   Amiodarone load then maintenance, which the pt was on in the past and
   stopped due to liver/lung issues. We have elected not to restart the
   Amiodarone due to this history of issues, but have started him on Dig
   instead.
   - Dig level is not elevated, will continue dosage as is.
   - Received some IV Labatelol yesterday
   - Increase Metoprolol to 37.5 PO bid today
   3. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt was on Cefepime/[**Name (NI) **], but yesterday d/c'd [**Name (NI) **]
   - Today is day 6 of Cefepime
   4. Fluid status--CXR with mild-mod pulm edema yesterday
   - Currently on Lasix gtt, will continue, now at 15mg / hr with goals
   150 cc/hr and 1-2L off per day.
   - Still about 5L positive today through LOS, but this may not reflect
   the 9L taken off during first para.
   5. Positive UA--Yesterday. On admission, concern for urosepsis but UCx
   only grow out <[**2112**] GNR's. Now with UA conerning for infxn yesterday,
   and have sent off UCx this am. Having low grade 100 temps for a couple
   days. WBC's at 9
   - F/u UCx.
   - Continues on Cefepime.
   - Hold off on starting new ABx for now but will consider broadening if
   urine Cx grows out
   6. Loculated pleural effusions, R > L.
   - Unsure what to do with this result in face of overall goals of care.
   Will be addressed at family meeting today whether to be aggressive with
   this or not.
   - Will need f/u of final CT read
   7. UA with persistent eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial
   nephritis, in setting of persistently elevated Cr. DDx includes
   allergic rxn to drugs, infxns including pyelonephritis, and
   infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma, leukemia.
   - Renal consult this am about eosinophilia.
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess for pyelonephritis
   8. Drifting down Hct: Has been slowly going down through admission and
   likely a consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to
   argatroban. No obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Watch vitals signs
   - Will get pm Hct
   - Has triple lumen subclavian and L PIV
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   8. Persistent respiratory failure: Reportedly on vent for the last 6
   mos.  Failure to wean could be both pneumonia as well as component of
   weakness, echo findings of RV dysfunction suggesting possible PE
   (unable to anticoagulate d/t persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or
   persistent pleural effusions due to persistent ascites.
   - Had SBT yesterday but got tachy and sweaty after several hours so put
   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   5. H/o HIT with need to be anticoagulated. LENI's are negative
   - Started on Argatroban gtt for PE prophylaxis per Heme recs with goal
   PTT 40-60
   - Currently within range at 0.2 mcg/kg/hr with PTT 50 so will continue
   as is
   10. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Have increased free water boluses via G tube to 250cc q4
   - Measure pm Na
   NON ACTIVE:
   7. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   9. Acute on Chronic Renal failure: Likely a chronic renal insufficiency
   with Cr
s in the 2
s on admission. Lasix diuresis at OSH was also
   limited by renal failure. Of note, UA came back positive for urine
   eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial nephritis.
   - Will get repeat UA, lytes, and urine eos to re-evaluate. If positive,
   would ask renal if they would treat for this AIN
   - Cr is chronically elevated, but will continue to trend.  Is 2.5 this
   morning, was 2.7 yesterday.
   - renally dose meds
   - Watch UOP through today
   11. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   12. S/P CABG: Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   13. Depression:
   - Continue Paxil
   14. "Funny Carotids" No signs of stroke, neuro exam WNL. Not an active
   issue.
   - carotid dopplers with <40% stenosis
   - not active issue
   15. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   16. G-tube malfunction: functioning per surgery, Radiology and nursing.
   Surgery has signed off. Not an active issue
   FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, systemic Argatroban
   Access: L subclavian triple lumen. R art line, L PIV
 will d/c

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, ascites, atrial fibrillation, and chronic respiratory failure. The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated for pneumonia, sepsis, and acute kidney injury.

The patient's current medical issues include:

1. Large amount of ascites: The patient has a significant amount of ascites, which is being managed with paracentesis and albumin infusions.
2. Moderate bilateral pleural effusions: The patient has moderate bilateral pleural effusions, which are being managed with pleural drainage and tube thoracostomy.
3. Separation of sternal wound: The patient has a separation of the sternal wound, which is concerning for dehiscence.
4. Gastrostomy tube: The patient has a gastrostomy tube, which is functioning properly.
5. Foley catheter: The patient has a Foley catheter, which is positioned in the proximal urethra with an inflated balloon.
6. Liver failure: The patient has cirrhosis and liver failure, which is being managed with albumin infusions and liver transplantation evaluation.
7. Arrhythmia: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with amiodarone and digoxin.
8. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which is being managed with antibiotics and respiratory support.
9. Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute kidney injury, which is being managed with fluid restriction, diuretics, and renal replacement therapy.
10. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 9.1 K/uL, Hct 25.7%, Plt 380 K/uL
* Electrolytes: Na 147 mEq/L, K 3.8 mEq/L, Cl 107 mg/dL, HCO3 23.0%
* Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN): 45 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 2.5 mg/dL
* Lactic Acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 0.16 ng/mL
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* Glucose: 124 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies are as follows:

* Chest X-ray: Shows moderate-to-severe pulmonary edema.
* CT chest without contrast: Shows moderate bilateral pleural effusions and a small pericardial effusion.
* CT abdomen/pelvis: Shows cirrhotic liver with ascites and a small pericardial effusion.

The patient's medication list is as follows:

* Antibiotics: Cefepime, Ciprofloxacin
* Anti-arrhythmics: Amiodarone, Digoxin
* Diuretics: Furosemide
* Anticoagulants: Argatroban
* Sedatives: Seroquel
* Antidepressants: Paxil

The patient's plan of care is as follows:

* Continue to manage the patient's ascites with paracentesis and albumin infusions.
* Continue to manage the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and respiratory support.
* Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with fluid restriction, diuretics, and renal replacement therapy.
* Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation.
* Continue to manage the patient's arrhythmia with amiodarone and digoxin.
* Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and consider liver transplantation evaluation.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid management accordingly.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust anti-arrhythmics as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and adjust sedation as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's pain and adjust analgesics as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's overall condition and adjust plan of care as needed.

   atrial tachycardia/AFib presenting for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube

s, so unlikely a true infection and

   with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated IgG, and had
   significant ascites that has been 9L tapped, and now s/p a second tap
   to assess for resolution. Current active issues are the
   etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and

   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing
   loculated effusions.
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  ?
   mental status could be due to ammonia levels?
   - continue cefepime.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   Patient was found to have cirrhosis and ascites on imaging.  Positive
   [**Doctor First Name **], positive anti-smooth muscle Ab and elevated IgG, consistent with
   autoimmune hepatitis etiology.
   - F/u Cx's from most recent para yesterday
   - F/u with Hepatology today
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Seen by renal yesterday.  Thought
   etiology ATN and AIN given elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended
   bladder pressure and renal USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils,
   concerning for acute interstitial nephritis, in setting of persistently
   elevated Cr. DDx includes allergic rxn to drugs, infxns including
   pyelonephritis, and infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma,
   leukemia.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for
   - f/u bladder pressure
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.  Dig level this
   morning is reassuring.
   - Dig level is not elevated, will continue dosage as is.
   - Will get Dig level tomorrow morning
   - Received some IV Labatelol yesterday
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt was on Cefepime/[**Name (NI) **], but yesterday d/c'd [**Name (NI) **]
   - Today is day 7 of Cefepime of 15 day course
   #. Positive UA--Yesterday. On admission, concern for urosepsis but UCx
   only grow out <[**2112**] GNR's. Now with UA conerning for infxn yesterday,
   and have sent off UCx this am. Having low grade 100 temps for a couple
   days. WBC's at 9
   - F/u UCx.
   - Continues on Cefepime.
   - Hold off on starting new ABx for now but will consider broadening if
   urine Cx grows out
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: IP will do a thoracentesis today.
   Patient changed to argatroban in preparation.
   Reportedly on vent for the last 6 mos.  Failure to wean could be both
   pneumonia as well as component of weakness, echo findings of RV
   dysfunction suggesting possible PE (unable to anticoagulate d/t
   persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or persistent pleural effusions
   due to persistent ascites.
   - Had SBT yesterday but got tachy and sweaty after several hours so put
   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   #. Loculated pleural effusions, R > L.
   - Unsure what to do with this result in face of overall goals of care.
   Will be addressed at family meeting today whether to be aggressive with
   this or not.
   - Will need f/u of final CT read
   - Consult IP about draining them today, and if we proceed, will need to
   have Argatroban stopped for procedure.
   #. Anemia: Has been slowly going down through admission and likely a
   consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to argatroban. No
   obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes. Had iron studies
   this admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia
   of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most recent UA, but urine is
   clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be hemodynamically relevant,
   but will need to watch and consider if continued drop in Hct.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Watch vitals signs
   - Will get pm Hct
   - Has triple lumen subclavian and L PIV
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Will increase free water via G tube to 300 q4hrs, but is a delicate
   balance between lowering pt
s hypernatremia and trying to get fluids
   off him with Lasix gtt
   - Measure pm Na
   #. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound.
   Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   #. Depression:
   - Continue Paxil
   #. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, systemic Argatroban

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman who was admitted to the ICU with signs of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and respiratory failure. He has a history of cirrhosis, ascites, and autoimmune hepatitis. He has been on ventilator support for the last 6 months and has failed to wean off the ventilator. He has also developed loculated pleural effusions and has been experiencing delirium and agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and his current condition may be worsening due to the presence of loculated pleural effusions and ongoing infection.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to pneumonia, pleural effusions, or chronic lung disease. He requires continued ventilator support and may require a tracheostomy.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and his creatinine level is increasing. He may require further management of his renal function, including diuretics and dialysis.
4. Arrhythmia: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and his current condition may be worsening due to the presence of electrolyte imbalances and medication side effects.
5. Pneumonia: The patient has a culture-positive Pseudomonas infection, and his respiratory failure may be worsening due to the presence of pneumonia.
6. Liver Failure: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, and his liver function may be worsening due to the presence of loculated pleural effusions and ongoing infection.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypovolemic hypernatremia, and his sodium level is increasing. He requires further management of his electrolyte imbalances, including the use of diuretics and fluid replacement.
8. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension, and his blood pressure may be worsening due to the presence of sepsis and ongoing infection.
9. Agitation/Delirium: The patient has been experiencing agitation and delirium, and his condition may be worsening due to the presence of electrolyte imbalances, medication side effects, and ongoing infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess his condition and respond to any changes.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with ventilator support and consider a tracheostomy if necessary.
3. Manage the patient's renal failure with diuretics and dialysis as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's arrhythmia with anti-arrhythmic medications and consider cardioversion if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and consider bronchoscopy if necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's liver failure with diuretics and fluid replacement as necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with diuretics and fluid replacement as necessary.
8. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with vasopressors and fluid replacement as necessary.
9. Continue to manage the patient's agitation and delirium with sedation and consider consulting a psychiatrist if necessary.

Family Meeting:

A family meeting should be held to discuss the patient's condition and potential medical complications. The patient's daughter should be informed of his condition and potential treatment options. The patient's code status should be discussed, and his desire for DNR should be respected.

ICU Care:

The patient should continue to receive ICU care, including ventilator support, dialysis, and sedation as necessary. His condition should be closely monitored, and any changes should be promptly addressed.

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman who presented with signs of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and cirrhosis. He has a history of HIT, DVT prophylaxis, and chronic renal failure. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, sepsis, and acute kidney injury. He has been treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation, and diuretics, and has undergone a thoracentesis and a liver biopsy. His current condition is complicated by the presence of loculated pleural effusions, ascites, and chronic kidney disease.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, pleural effusions, and chronic kidney disease. He may require continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to Pseudomonas pneumonia and may require continued antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely due to ATN and AIN, and may require continued diuretic therapy and hemodialysis.
4. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis is likely contributing to his ascites, pleural effusions, and chronic kidney disease. He may require continued anticoagulation therapy and diuretic therapy.
5. Liver Failure: The patient's liver failure is likely contributing to his ascites, pleural effusions, and chronic kidney disease. He may require continued anticoagulation therapy and diuretic therapy.
6. Pseudomonas Pneumonia: The patient's Pseudomonas pneumonia may require continued antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.
7. Loculated Pleural Effusions: The patient's loculated pleural effusions may require continued thoracentesis and anticoagulation therapy.
8. Ascites: The patient's ascites may require continued diuretic therapy and anticoagulation therapy.
9. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease may require continued hemodialysis and anticoagulation therapy.
10. Depression: The patient's depression may require continued antidepressant therapy and psychological support.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy for Pseudomonas pneumonia and sepsis.
2. Continue diuretic therapy and anticoagulation therapy for ascites and chronic kidney disease.
3. Consider thoracentesis and anticoagulation therapy for loculated pleural effusions.
4. Continue hemodialysis for acute kidney injury.
5. Consider liver transplantation for cirrhosis and liver failure.
6. Continue antidepressant therapy and psychological support for depression.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust therapy as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust therapy as necessary.
10. Consider a multidisciplinary approach to manage the patient's complex medical condition.

   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   #. Anemia: Has been slowly going down through admission and likely a
   consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to argatroban. No
   obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes. Had iron studies
   this admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia
   of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most recent UA, but urine is
   clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be hemodynamically relevant,
   but will need to watch and consider if continued drop in Hct.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools

   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Will increase free water via G tube to 300 q4hrs, but is a delicate
   balance between lowering pt
s hypernatremia and trying to get fluids
   off him with Lasix gtt
   - Measure pm Na
   #. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well

   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound.
   Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.

Based on the patient's progress note, I have summarized the key information and potential medical complications that may arise:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a history of cirrhosis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and chronic respiratory failure.
* He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to pneumonia and pleural effusions.
* He has a positive urine culture for Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant to other antibiotics.
* He has a history of allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) and acute kidney injury (AKI).
* He has a liver failure, with a SAAG >1.1, making it difficult to distinguish between cirrhosis and right heart failure.
* He has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is on anticoagulation therapy.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Renal Failure:** The patient's AKI may worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
2. **Liver Failure:** The patient's liver function may continue to deteriorate, leading to increased risk of bleeding, infection, and death.
3. **Pneumonia:** The patient's pneumonia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, sepsis, and death.
4. **Pleural Effusions:** The patient's pleural effusions may continue to accumulate, leading to respiratory compromise and decreased lung function.
5. **Allergic Interstitial Nephritis (AIN):** The patient's AIN may worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease and increased risk of infection.
6. **Hypernatremia:** The patient's hypernatremia may worsen, leading to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of complications.
7. **Hypotension:** The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to decreased perfusion, organ dysfunction, and death.
8. **Delirium:** The patient's delirium may worsen, leading to increased risk of falls, aspiration, and death.
9. **Depression:** The patient's depression may worsen, leading to decreased quality of life, increased risk of suicide, and decreased response to treatment.
10. **Sepsis:** The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to multi-organ dysfunction, increased risk of death, and decreased response to treatment.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status.
2. Adjust antibiotic therapy based on the patient's response to treatment and the results of urine and blood cultures.
3. Consider switching from Cefipime to Aztreonam if the patient's urine culture grows out sensitive to Aztreonam.
4. Continue to manage the patient's pleural effusions with thoracentesis and chest tube placement.
5. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust therapy accordingly.
6. Consider increasing the patient's free water intake to manage his hypernatremia.
7. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust therapy accordingly to manage his hypotension.
8. Consider increasing the patient's dose of seroquel to manage his agitation and delirium.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's depression and adjust therapy accordingly.
10. Consider involving the patient's family in his care and providing them with education and support to manage his condition.

   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance.

   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His

   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,

   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with

s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again

   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, and a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). He is currently in the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and ascites. He has undergone several interventions, including thoracocentesis and arterial line placement.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Leukocytosis with an unclear source
* Liver failure with a SAAG > 1.1, suggesting cirrhosis or right heart failure
* Acute kidney injury with elevated FENa and eosinophilia on differential
* Respiratory failure with improvement with diuresis and thoracocentesis
* Hypernatremia with hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission
* Anemia with a stable microcytic anemia and low level iron
* Elevated liver enzymes, including AST and ALT
* Positive anti-smooth muscle antibody and elevated IgG, suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Liver failure: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and his SAAG is > 1.1, suggesting cirrhosis or right heart failure. This could lead to liver failure and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury could progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to respiratory arrest or death.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia could lead to central pontine myelinolysis or other complications.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
7. Arrhythmia: The patient's atrial fibrillation could worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or death.
8. Infection: The patient's positive blood cultures and leukocytosis suggest the possibility of infection, which could lead to sepsis and death.
9. Bleeding: The patient's history of HIT and the use of anticoagulants could increase his risk of bleeding.
10. Dehiscence of sternotomy wound: The patient's CT scan shows a concern for dehiscence of his sternotomy wound, which could lead to complications such as infection or bleeding.

Recommendations:

1. Continue diuresis and thoracocentesis to manage the patient's respiratory and ascites.
2. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and consider a liver biopsy to determine the etiology of his liver failure.
3. Continue antibiotics and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Consider changing the patient's antibiotic to aztreonam if it is sensitive to this antibiotic.
5. Monitor the patient's kidney function and consider dialysis if necessary.
6. Manage the patient's hypernatremia with aggressive correction and close monitoring.
7. Continue anticoagulation therapy and monitor for signs of bleeding.
8. Consider a liver transplant if the patient's liver failure is deemed irreversible.
9. Monitor the patient's arrhythmia and consider cardioversion if necessary.
10. Consider a TIPS procedure if the patient's ascites is recurrent.

   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning. His urine has grown out <[**2112**] GNR
s, so unlikely
   a true infection and no longer and active issue. He also has sputum
   with Pseudomonas, currently being treated, which likely is a true
   infection. In his workup at this hospital it was learned that he has a
   cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated
   IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and apparent SBP, and now
   s/p a second tap to assess for resolution. Current active issues are
   the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and
   managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most
   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing
   loculated effusions.
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be to
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Seen by renal yesterday.  Thought
   etiology ATN and AIN given elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended
   bladder pressure and renal USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, DDx
   includes allergic rxn to drugs (esp. PCNs and H2B), infxns including
   pyelonephritis, and infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma,
   leukemia.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u bladder pressure
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.  Dig level this
   morning is reassuring.  Will continue with current dosing.
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 7 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Likely a combination of pneumonia,
   pleural effusions and fluid overload.  IP will do a thoracentesis today
   which will hopefully provide some symptomatic relief.  If the tap helps
   and the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would like us to consider a
   TIPS procedure.  Patient changed to argatroban in preparation.
   - continue diuresis
   - Continue daily SBT/trach mask trials
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well, if stabilized we could maybe
   take A-line out tomorrow.
   #. Anemia: Has a stable microcytic anemia. Had iron studies this
   admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease.
   - Guiac all stools
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147.  We are currently holding free water as we await
   thoracocentesis.  If his PM Na is increased, can consider giving D5W.
   - Measure pm Na
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   - Continue PRN Seroquel 25mg
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT.
   This finding was also seen on previous CT, when cardiac surgery was
   consulted.  They were not concerned.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   #. Depression: - Continue Paxil
   #. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   FEN: Replete electrolytes, tube feeds can be restarted post-prcedure
   (Nutren)

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, and a history of urosepsis. He is currently admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute on chronic renal failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current medications include cefepime, lasix, and argatroban, with plans to switch to aztreonam if the sensitivity test is positive. He is also receiving lactulose for hepatic encephalopathy and seroquel for agitation.

The patient's lab results show elevated WBC, Hct, and platelet count, with a normal kidney function test. His liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated AST and ALT levels. His coagulation studies show a prolonged PT and PTT.

The patient's physical examination reveals tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. His skin is pale, and his mucous membranes are dry. His abdomen is tender to palpation, with ascites present.

The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 230. He is receiving oxygen therapy via a tracheostomy tube and is on a ventilator with a CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's gastrointestinal status is also compromised, with a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He is receiving lactulose for hepatic encephalopathy and is being monitored for electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's renal status is also compromised, with a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 109 mg/dL. He is receiving lasix for diuresis and is being monitored for electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's overall condition is unstable, with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) present. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate, leading to respiratory failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver function may worsen, leading to hepatic encephalopathy.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
6. Infection: The patient may develop a new infection, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection.
7. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) present. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration. Potential medical complications that may arise include sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, hepatic encephalopathy, electrolyte imbalances, infection, and bleeding.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning.  Being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia based on
   sputum cultures with cefepime. In his workup at this hospital it was
   learned that he has a cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and
   apparent SBP, and now s/p a second tap with improvement. Current active
   issues are the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis,
   managing the arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in
   sinus), managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy),
   and managing his trach/vent dependence w/ diuresis and thoracocentesis,
   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.
    .
   #. Leukocytosis: Today patient had abrupt rise in WBC of unclear
   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance. Sent for pan culture and all has
   been NTD. WBC count improving today.
   - CTM WBC and fevers
   - Continue cefipime, consider changing abio if not improving.  Also,
   consider changing if has [**Last Name (un) 270**] to aztreonam d/t AIN
   .
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - liver biopsy prior to discharge to better determine etiology of liver
   failure and ? autoimmune hepatitis.
   - hepatology recommends neostigmine if remains distended
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   .
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Thought etiology ATN and AIN given
   elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended bladder pressure and renal
   USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, and eosinophilia on
   differential.  Renal U/S normal.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u renal recs.
    .
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Has improved with combination of
   diuresis and thoracocentesis and today is tolerating trach mask trial
   longer than previously.  If the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would
   like us to consider a TIPS procedure.   On trach mask for >24hours and
   tolerating well.
   - continue diuresis PRN
   - restarted argatroban for DVT prophylaxis.
   .
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Now back up
   to 146, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.  We
   will be more aggressive in our correction, giving a 500cc D5W bolus.
   We can also resume 300cc free water flushes Q4hrs with tube feeds.
   - Give d5W to repair
   - Measure Na in aft.
   .
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.    Will continue
   with current dosing.
   .
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 9 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   .
   #. Anemia: Has a stable microcytic anemia. Had iron studies this
   admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease.  Hct improving.  Has known GI bleed
   - Continue to monitor Hct daily
   - Transfuse for <21
   .
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   - Continue PRN Seroquel 25mg
   .
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT.
   This finding was also seen on previous CT, when cardiac surgery was
   consulted.  They were not concerned.
   - continue ASA, stopped statin given elevated LFTs.
   .
   #. Depression: - Continue Paxil
   .
   #. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   .
   FEN: Replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, Argatroban
   Access: L PICC.  L PIV.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning.  Being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia based on
   sputum cultures with cefepime. In his workup at this hospital it was
   learned that he has a cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and
   apparent SBP, and now s/p a second tap with improvement. Current active
   issues are the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis,
   managing the arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in
   sinus), managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy),
   and managing his trach/vent dependence w/ diuresis and thoracocentesis,
   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.
    .
   #. Leukocytosis: Today patient had abrupt rise in WBC of unclear
   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance. Sent for pan culture and all has
   been NTD. WBC count improving today.
   - CTM WBC and fevers
   - Continue cefipime, consider changing abio if not improving.  Also,
   consider changing if has [**Last Name (un) 270**] to aztreonam d/t AIN
   .
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - liver biopsy prior to discharge to better determine etiology of liver
   failure and ? autoimmune hepatitis.
   - hepatology recommends neostigmine if remains distended
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   .
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Thought etiology ATN and AIN given
   elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended bladder pressure and renal
   USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, and eosinophilia on
   differential.  Renal U/S normal.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u renal recs.
    .
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Has improved with combination of
   diuresis and thoracocentesis and today is tolerating trach mask trial
   longer than previously.  If the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would
   like us to consider a TIPS procedure.   On trach mask for >24hours and
   tolerating well.
   - continue diuresis PRN
   - restarted argatroban for DVT prophylaxis.
   .
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Now back up
   to 146, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.  We
   will be more aggressive in our correction, giving a 500cc D5W bolus.
   We can also resume 300cc free water flushes Q4hrs with tube feeds.
   - Give d5W to repair
   - Measure Na in aft.
   .
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.    Will continue
   with current dosing.
   .
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 9 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   .
   #. Anemia: Has a stable microcytic anemia. Had iron studies this
   admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease.  Hct improving.  Has known GI bleed
   - Continue to monitor Hct daily
   - Transfuse for <21
   .
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   - Continue PRN Seroquel 25mg
   .
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT.
   This finding was also seen on previous CT, when cardiac surgery was
   consulted.  They were not concerned.
   - continue ASA, stopped statin given elevated LFTs.
   .
   #. Depression: - Continue Paxil
   .
   #. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   .
   FEN: Replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, Argatroban

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old man with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, and a recent gastrointestinal tube insertion. He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient has been treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia with cefepime, but has developed a new leukocytosis, which is unclear in origin. He also has acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Leukocytosis: The patient's new leukocytosis may be a sign of an underlying infection or inflammation. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of this increase.
2. Liver Failure: The patient's cirrhosis is worsening, and he has a high risk of developing liver failure. He is being treated with lactulose to help manage his ammonia levels.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has developed acute renal failure, which may be due to his cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, or other underlying conditions. He is being treated with diuresis and may need to consider a liver biopsy before discharge.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient has persistent respiratory failure, which may be due to his cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, or other underlying conditions. He is being treated with diuresis and thoracocentesis.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which may be contributing to his altered mental status. He is being treated with a 500cc D5W bolus and will have his sodium levels rechecked.
6. Arrhythmia: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is being treated with digoxin.
7. PNA: The patient has Pseudomonas pneumonia, which is being treated with cefepime.
8. Anemia: The patient has a stable microcytic anemia, which may be due to his cirrhosis or other underlying conditions.
9. Agitation/Delirium: The patient has agitation and delirium, which may be due to his cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, or other underlying conditions. He is being treated with seroquel.
10. S/P CABG: The patient has concerns about dehiscence of his sternotomy wound, which may require further evaluation.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and treat accordingly.
2. Continue to manage the patient's liver failure with lactulose and consider a liver biopsy before discharge.
3. Continue to treat the patient's acute renal failure with diuresis and consider a liver biopsy before discharge.
4. Continue to treat the patient's respiratory failure with diuresis and thoracocentesis.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hypernatremia and treat accordingly.
6. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with digoxin.
7. Continue to treat the patient's PNA with cefepime.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and treat accordingly.
9. Continue to treat the patient's agitation and delirium with seroquel.
10. Consider further evaluation of the patient's sternotomy wound.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, the following medical complications and potential issues are identified:

1. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has abruptly risen, with unclear source. The patient is being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia with cefepime, but the source of the leukocytosis is unclear. The patient is not on steroids, and there is no clear stressor or infectious source.
2. Liver Failure: The patient has cirrhosis with a SAAG >1.1, making it difficult to distinguish between cirrhosis and right heart failure. The patient's altered mental status may be due to ammonia and decreased hepatic clearance. The patient is being treated with lactulose.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has elevated FENa off of diuretics, suggesting ATN and AIN. The patient's UA has persistent eosinophils, and eosinophilia on differential. Renal USG is normal.
4. Persistent Respiratory Failure: The patient has improved with diuresis and thoracocentesis, but the effusion is recurrent. Hepatology recommends considering a TIPS procedure if the effusion recurs.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission, which is now improving. The patient will receive a 500cc D5W bolus and resume 300cc free water flushes Q4hrs with tube feeds.
6. Arrhythmia: The patient was in atrial tachycardia/AFib on admission, but is now in sinus rhythm. The patient is being treated with digoxin.
7. PNA: The patient has Pseudomonas pneumonia, which is sensitive to cefepime but resistant to ciprofloxacin. The patient's antibiotic course is 15 days, and sensitivities to aztreonam will be checked for possible switch.
8. Anemia: The patient has a stable microcytic anemia, which is likely due to anemia of chronic disease. The patient's Hct is improving, and the patient has known GI bleed.
9. Agitation/Delirium: The patient has been started on seroquel and appears to be tolerating it well.
10. S/P CABG: The patient has a concern about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT, which was also seen on previous CT. The patient's cardiac surgery consult was not concerned.
11. Depression: The patient is being treated with Paxil.
12. DM: The patient has insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, with no standing for now.

The patient's current medications include:

* Argatroban for DVT prophylaxis
* Cefepime for Pseudomonas pneumonia
* Furosemide (Lasix) for diuresis
* Lansoprazole (Prevacid) for PPI
* Seroquel for agitation/delirium
* Digoxin for arrhythmia
* Paxil for depression
* Tube feeds (Nutren)

The patient's access includes a L PICC and L PIV. The patient's code is DNR, and they are already tracheally intubated. The patient's communication is with their daughter, who can be reached at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home) and [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**] (cell). The patient's disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.
